['Page 6:
[¬s]"The two training groups in each school (phonemic
training and alternative training) were taught for 20 min each
week, for a period of 15 weeks. This added up to a total training
time of 5 hr for each group. The third group in each school (unseen
control) was not given any teaching by the researcher. This group
was only given pretests and posttests. Lessons for each group were
rehearsed with another group of children outside the experiment to
ensure that our presentation of the lessons would run smoothly. We
opened each lesson with an overview of the lesson content and a
revision of previous learning. The aims for the lesson were also
reviewed at the close of the lesson.
The phonemic training group focused on segmentation and
blending skills. These often revolved around a target word that was
embedded within a short, easy-to-recall rhyme or jingle. However,
to control for the effect of the reading rhymes, we also had the
alternative training control group read these rhymes.
The skills taught during phonemic training included alliteration
(e.g., big, bad, bug) and rhyme (e.g., fat, rat). Segmentation
activities involved using the Elkonin technique (Clay, 1985),
wherein children place tokens into squares that represent the
phonemic structure of words. Other activities involved games,
where children had to decide which picture cards started the same,
ended the same, or had the same middle sound. Children were also
taught to blend sounds (e.g., mmooo = moo) and how to delete
sounds (e.g., meat without the m says eat). The program was
adapted in part from that described by Williams (1979, 1980) with
7 consonants (b, c, g, m, p, s, t) and two short vowels (o, a) selected
for initial training. We selected these to avoid visual and auditory
confusability. Also, they produced a high number of consonant-
vowel-consonant (CVC) real words, and they showed regularity
of phonemes in spelling patterns. A second set of phonemes was
later introduced when segmenting and blending skills were well
established with the first set. Additional activities were adapted
from the list of phonemic tasks recommended in Lewkowicz
(1980). Later in the training program, we replaced counters with
letters in sound games, and we used plastic letters in substitution
exercises (on the basis of Bradley & Bryant, 1983).[¬e]"']

[¬s]"The Early Reading Research (ERR) therefore introduces phonological awareness
training into a broader context which focuses on a range of skills and teaching methods.
It represents a change in emphasis from much psychological research which typically
explores the relationship between phonological skills and reading, but rarely addresses
the school-based instructional factors which also contribute to children's progress in
reading. As a result, a framework for teaching reading was developed in response to
questions raised by the LEA funding the research who wanted to explore (i) whether
difficulties in reading could be prevented by early intervention with beginning readers
and (ii) the extent to which the research into reading and instruction could be
translated into effective classroom-based interventions. The framework draws on in-
structional psychology, introduces schools to novel instructional approaches, only
teaches phonological skills which are seen to be explicitly used in the reading and
spelling processes, and has developed procedures to ensure that children can apply the
skills they learn to reading a wide range of texts. The purpose of this stage of the
research is to demonstrate that the reading framework is having a significant impact on
children's learning. Further research will be undertaken to investigate the specific role
of different skills and strategies within the framework should it be shown that it leads
to an improvement in children's reading.[¬e]"']
